A Huber Loss Minimization Approach to Byzantine Robust Federated Learning

Puning Zhao, Fei Yu, Zhiguo Wan
Zhejiang Lab
Hangzhou, Zhejiang, China
{pnzhao,yufei,wanzhiguo}@zhejianglab.com
Abstract

Federated learning systems are susceptible to adversarial attacks. To combat this, we introduce a novel aggregator based on Huber loss minimization, and provide a comprehensive theoretical analysis. Under independent and identically distributed (i.i.d) assumption, our approach has several advantages compared to existing methods. Firstly, it has optimal dependence on Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, which stands for the ratio of attacked clients. Secondly, our approach does not need precise knowledge of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. Thirdly, it allows different clients to have unequal data sizes. We then broaden our analysis to include non-i.i.d data, such that clients have slightly different distributions.

1 Introduction

Due to privacy concerns, there are a large number of isolated information islands, resulting in the difficulty of integrating data from various sources. Under such background, a novel machine learning framework called Federated Learning (FL) has arisen in recent years [1]. FL consists of numerous clients that store and compute data locally, and a central server that plays the role as a coordinator. In comparison to traditional centralized learning, FL offers distinct advantages in terms of both computational efficiency and privacy protection. As a result, FL is gaining increasing attention and has been widely applied in various domains, including mobile devices, industrial engineering, and healthcare [2, 3].

Nevertheless, FL is facing several severe challenges [4], with one of them being the robustness issue. Due to various factors, including data poisoning, system malfunctions and transmission errors, some clients may send wrong gradient vectors to the server. Consider that these abnormal behaviors are hard to predict and may happen in an unknown manner, it suffices to analyze the most harmful attack, which is typically modeled as Byzantine failure [5]. Under this model, an adversary can modify the gradient values uploaded to the master in arbitrary way. Without proper handling, even a single malicious client can significantly degrade the model performance [6]. Therefore, for the safe deployment of FL, it is important to design effective defense strategies robust to Byzantine attacks.

There have been many existing works on Byzantine robust federated learning problems. In particular, various gradient aggregators have been proposed. Krum [7] picks the gradient vector uploaded from clients with small nearest neighbor distances. However, the global convergence is not guaranteed. [8] proposed a geometric median-of-mean method, which ensures that the model weights converge to a point near to the global minimum, as long as Ïµ<1/2italic-Ïµ12\epsilon<1/2, with Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon being the fraction of Byzantine machines. This method is not perfect since the error has a suboptimal rate of O~â€‹(Ïµâ€‹d)~ğ‘‚italic-Ïµğ‘‘\tilde{O}(\sqrt{\epsilon d}). [9] analyzed two aggregators. The first one, called coordinate-wise median, is suboptimal if the sample size per client nğ‘›n is smaller than the number of clients mğ‘šm. Unfortunately, this is quite likely in practice. The second one is coordinate-wise trimmed mean, which has optimal dependence with Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon when Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is small. However, as will be discussed later, if Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is close to 1/2121/2, then coordinate-wise trimmed mean is not efficient. Another drawback is that this method needs the precise knowledge of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, which is usually not practical. Moreover, the analysis of these previous methods are based on some simplified assumption, including independent and identically distributed (i.i.d) assumption, and that all clients have nearly equal sample sizes. More theoretical analysis is needed in realistic scenarios with heterogeneous and unbalanced data.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to Byzantine robust federated learning, which aggregates gradients by minimizing a multi-dimensional Huber loss. As a widely used loss function in robust statistics [10, 11, 12, 13], Huber loss combines the advantages of â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1} and â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} loss, and achieves a tradeoff between robustness and consistency. However, the original definition of Huber loss was for scalars. We generalize the original definition, to make it suitable for vectors. In each iteration, given a list of gradient vectors uploaded from clients, the new algorithm obtains the estimated gradient of the underlying global risk function by minimizing the generalized Huber loss, and then use the outcome as the direction of parameter update.

We then provide theoretical analysis of the proposed method. To begin with, it is assumed that training samples are i.i.d, which is common in most of existing works on Byzantine robust FL [8, 7, 9]. Under i.i.d assumption, two error bounds are derived for balanced and unbalanced data, respectively. Consider that i.i.d assumption may not be realistic, we then make some generalization to allow heterogeneous clients. The result shows that our method is robust to moderate violation of i.i.d assumption. There are several recent works [14, 15, 16, 17] that deal with heterogeneous data. These works are mainly designed for the case that the differences between clients are large. In slightly heterogeneous regime, these methods can not achieve comparable statistical rates.

Finally, we discuss how to implement our new algorithm. Our design is motivated by Weiszfeldâ€™s algorithm for calculating the geometric median of a set of vectors [18]. We make some adjustments to Weiszfeldâ€™s algorithm, such that it can minimize the multi-dimensional Huber loss.

In general, compared with existing methods, our new approach has several advantages. Firstly, the dependence of statistical risk on the attack ratio Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is nearly minimax optimal, up to a logarithm factor. Secondly, our method has desirable performance with unbalanced data. In particular, with an adaptive rule of parameter selection, the statistical rate is the same as the case with balanced data. Thirdly, many existing methods require the precise knowledge of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon to set parameters, which is usually not practical. On the contrary, our method works well under the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-agnostic settings.

Our contributions are summarized as follows:

  • â€¢

    A multi-dimensional Huber loss minimization approach to robust federated learning;

  • â€¢

    Theoretical analysis of our method for both balanced and unbalanced data under i.i.d assumption, which also provides a guideline of parameter selection;

  • â€¢

    Extension of the analysis above to heterogeneous clients;

  • â€¢

    An implementation algorithm of multi-dimensional Huber loss minimization;

  • â€¢

    Numerical experiments on both synthesized and real data, which validates the effectiveness of our new method.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. The problem statement and the proposed method are shown in SectionÂ 2. The theoretical analysis with and without i.i.d assumption are shown in Section 3 and 4, respectively. In SectionÂ 5, we describe our implementation algorithm. Furthermore, we compare our approach with existing methods in SectionÂ 6. Finally, numerical experiments and concluding remarks are shown in SectionÂ 7 and 8, respectively.

2 The Proposed Method

In this section, we make a precise statement of the framework of the federated learning problem, and then introduce our proposed aggregator based on minimization of multi-dimensional Huber loss.

The framework is shown in Algorithm 1. Suppose there is a server S0subscriptğ‘†0S_{0} and mğ‘šm clients S1,â€¦,Smsubscriptğ‘†1â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘šS_{1},\ldots,S_{m}. Denote â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} as the set of Byzantine clients. There are Nğ‘N training samples in total, with each client Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i} storing nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} of them. Denote ğ™iâ€‹jsubscriptğ™ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{Z}_{ij} as the jğ‘—j-th sample in the iğ‘–i-th client, jâˆˆ{1,â€¦,ni}ğ‘—1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–j\in\{1,\ldots,n_{i}\}. Let fâ€‹(ğ°,ğ³)ğ‘“ğ°ğ³f(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{z}) be the loss function of model parameter ğ°âˆˆğ’²ğ°ğ’²\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W} with respect to sample ğ³ğ³\mathbf{z}, in which ğ’²âŠ‚â„dğ’²superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{W}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} is the parameter space. Moreover, define the global risk function as

Fâ€‹(ğ°)=ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(ğ°,ğ™)],ğ¹ğ°ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“ğ°ğ™\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w})=\mathbb{E}[f(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{Z})], (1)

in which ğ™ğ™\mathbf{Z} follows the global distribution of training samples. In particular, under i.i.d assumption, ğ™ğ™\mathbf{Z} just follows the distribution of arbitrary ğ™iâ€‹jsubscriptğ™ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{Z}_{ij}. Otherwise, with heterogeneous clients, ğ™ğ™\mathbf{Z} follows the average distribution of clients weighted by nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i}. The goal is to learn the global minimizer

ğ°âˆ—=argâ¡minğ°âˆˆğ’²â€‹Fâ€‹(ğ°).superscriptğ°ğ°ğ’²ğ¹ğ°\displaystyle\mathbf{w}^{*}=\underset{\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W}}{\arg\min}F(\mathbf{w}). (2)

The algorithm starts with an initial parameter ğ°0âˆˆğ’²subscriptğ°0ğ’²\mathbf{w}_{0}\in\mathcal{W}, At each iteration t=0,1,â€¦ğ‘¡01â€¦t=0,1,\ldots, we find an update ğ°t+1subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1\mathbf{w}_{t+1}. Ideally, it would be better if we know âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}), so that we can use a simple gradient descent to update ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w}, i.e. ğ°t+1=ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡\mathbf{w}_{t+1}=\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}), in which Î·ğœ‚\eta is the learning rate. However, âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}) is unknown in practice. We need to estimate it using the gradient vectors uploaded from clients. Therefore, at each iteration tğ‘¡t, the master broadcasts parameter ğ°tsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡\mathbf{w}_{t} to all clients, and then wait for the responses from them. Benign clients send the estimated gradient vectors back to the master, with respect to parameter ğ°tsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡\mathbf{w}_{t}. On the contrary, Byzantine clients send arbitrary vectors determined by the adversary. To be more precise, denote ğ—iâ€‹tsubscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ‘¡\mathbf{X}_{it} as the vector received from client iğ‘–i at the tğ‘¡t-th iteration, then

ğ—iâ€‹tsubscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ‘¡\displaystyle\mathbf{X}_{it} =\displaystyle= {1niâ€‹âˆ‘j=1niâˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ°t,ğ™iâ€‹j)ifiâˆ‰â„¬â‹†ifiâˆˆâ„¬,cases1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğ™ğ‘–ğ‘—ifğ‘–â„¬â‹†ifğ‘–â„¬\displaystyle\left\{\begin{array}[]{ccc}\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t},\mathbf{Z}_{ij})&\text{if}&i\notin\mathcal{B}\\ \star&\text{if}&i\in\mathcal{B},\end{array}\right. (5)

in which â‹†â‹†\star means arbitrary vector determined by the adversary. After received ğ—iâ€‹tsubscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ‘¡\mathbf{X}_{it} for all i=1,â€¦,mğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘ši=1,\ldots,m, the master then updates the parameter ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w} according to the following rule:

ğ°t+1=Î ğ’²â€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t)),subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1subscriptÎ ğ’²subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{t+1}=\Pi_{\mathcal{W}}(\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t})), (6)

in which Î ğ’²â€‹(â‹…)subscriptÎ ğ’²â‹…\Pi_{\mathcal{W}}(\cdot) is an Euclidean projection operator, which ensures that the model parameter stays in ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W}. This operator is also used in [9, 19]. Î·ğœ‚\eta is the learning rate. gâ€‹(ğ°t)ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡g(\mathbf{w}_{t}) is the aggregator function, which estimates âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}) using ğ—iâ€‹tsubscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ‘¡\mathbf{X}_{it}, i=1,â€¦,mğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘ši=1,\ldots,m.

Now it remains to design the aggregator function gâ€‹(ğ°t)ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡g(\mathbf{w}_{t}). Our idea is to minimize the Huber loss weighted by the sample sizes in each clients:

gâ€‹(ğ°t)=argâ¡minğ‘ â€‹âˆ‘i=1mniâ€‹Ï•iâ€‹(âˆ¥ğ¬âˆ’ğ—iâ€‹tâˆ¥),ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ¬subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ‘¡\displaystyle g(\mathbf{w}_{t})=\underset{s}{\arg\min}\sum_{i=1}^{m}n_{i}\phi_{i}(\left\lVert\mathbf{s}-\mathbf{X}_{it}\right\rVert), (7)

in which âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥â‹…\left\lVert\cdot\right\rVert is the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} norm, and

Ï•iâ€‹(u)={12â€‹u2if|u|â‰¤TiTiâ€‹uâˆ’12â€‹Ti2if|u|>Tisubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–ğ‘¢cases12superscriptğ‘¢2ifğ‘¢subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–ğ‘¢12superscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–2ifğ‘¢subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–\displaystyle\phi_{i}(u)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ccc}\frac{1}{2}u^{2}&\text{if}&|u|\leq T_{i}\\ T_{i}u-\frac{1}{2}T_{i}^{2}&\text{if}&|u|>T_{i}\end{array}\right. (10)

is the Huber loss function. If clients have equal or nearly equal sample size nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i}, then we can let Tisubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–T_{i} to be the same for all iğ‘–i. Otherwise, we may use different Tisubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–T_{i}. With larger nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i}, we let Tisubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–T_{i} to be smaller. We refer detailed discussion on parameter selection to Section 3 and 4.

Now we explain the intuition of such design. We have two requirements for a good aggregator: consistency without attack, and robustness under attack. Minimizing â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} loss corresponds to a simple averaging gaâ€‹vâ€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t)=(1/m)â€‹âˆ‘i=1niğ—iâ€‹tsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ‘¡g_{avg}(\mathbf{w}_{t})=(1/m)\sum_{i=1}^{n_{i}}\mathbf{X}_{it}, which is consistent without attack, but not robust. On the contrary, minimizing â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1} loss yields the geometric median of ğ—iâ€‹tsubscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ‘¡\mathbf{X}_{it}, i=1,â€¦,mğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘ši=1,\ldots,m, which is robust but not consistent even without attack. Therefore, we minimize Huber loss, which combines the advantages of these two methods. At the limit Tiâ†’âˆâ†’subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–T_{i}\rightarrow\infty, Ï•isubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–\phi_{i} becomes â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} loss, then gâ€‹(ğ°t)ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡g(\mathbf{w}_{t}) is just the sample mean gaâ€‹vâ€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡g_{avg}(\mathbf{w}_{t}). The opposite limit is Tiâ†’0â†’subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–0T_{i}\rightarrow 0, under which gâ€‹(ğ°t)ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡g(\mathbf{w}_{t}) is actually the weighted geometric median of ğ—iâ€‹tsubscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ‘¡\mathbf{X}_{it}, i=1,â€¦,mğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘ši=1,\ldots,m. Between these two extremes, we can set appropriate Tisubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–T_{i} to achieve a good tradeoff between consistency and Byzantine robustness.

In the following sections, we provide a theoretical analysis of the performance of our method. Following previous works [9, 19], we discuss three cases separately, which are stated in Assumption 1:

Assumption 1.

Consider the following three types of global loss function Fğ¹F:

(a) (Strong convex) Fğ¹F is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strong convex and Lğ¿L-smooth, and ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W} is convex;

(b) (General convex) Fğ¹F is convex and Lğ¿L-smooth, with ğ’²={ğ°|âˆ¥ğ°âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â‰¤2â€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥}ğ’²conditional-setğ°delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ°superscriptğ°2delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°\mathcal{W}=\{\mathbf{w}|\left\lVert\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq 2\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\};

(c) (Non-convex) Fğ¹F is Lğ¿L-smooth, and âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ¥â‰¤Mdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹ğ°ğ‘€\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\right\rVert\leq M for all ğ°âˆˆğ’²ğ°ğ’²\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W}.

For all these three cases, we make the following common assumption on the covering number, which ensures the uniform convergence of the aggregator function:

Assumption 2.

Assume that there exists constants CWsubscriptğ¶ğ‘ŠC_{W}, rDsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ·r_{D}, such that for all r<rDğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ·r<r_{D}, the rğ‘Ÿr-covering of ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W} is bounded by Ncâ€‹(r)â‰¤CW/rdsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ¶ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘‘N_{c}(r)\leq C_{W}/r^{d}.

Before diving into the detailed analysis, we clarify the notations used in the remainder of this paper first.

Notations. Throughout this paper, we use the following notations: aâ‰²bless-than-or-similar-toğ‘ğ‘a\lesssim b if there exists a constant Cğ¶C such that aâ‰¤Câ€‹bğ‘ğ¶ğ‘a\leq Cb. Cğ¶C may depend on Î¼ğœ‡\mu, Ïƒğœ\sigma, Lğ¿L and CWsubscriptğ¶ğ‘ŠC_{W} in the assumptions. Conversely, aâ‰³bgreater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘ğ‘a\gtrsim b means aâ‰¥Câ€‹bğ‘ğ¶ğ‘a\geq Cb. Moreover, aâˆ¼bsimilar-toğ‘ğ‘a\sim b means there exists two constants C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1} and C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2} such that C1â€‹bâ‰¤aâ‰¤C2â€‹bsubscriptğ¶1ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ¶2ğ‘C_{1}b\leq a\leq C_{2}b. Furthermore, a=O~â€‹(b)ğ‘~ğ‘‚ğ‘a=\tilde{O}(b) means aâ‰¤Câ€‹bâ€‹lnkâ¡(N/Î´)ğ‘ğ¶ğ‘superscriptğ‘˜ğ‘ğ›¿a\leq Cb\ln^{k}(N/\delta) for some constants Cğ¶C and kğ‘˜k. Denote [m]={1,â€¦,m}delimited-[]ğ‘š1â€¦ğ‘š[m]=\{1,\ldots,m\} as the set of numbers from 111 to mğ‘šm. Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, qğ‘q are the ratio and the number of Byzantine clients, respectively, with q=Ïµâ€‹mğ‘italic-Ïµğ‘šq=\epsilon m. Finally, âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥â‹…\left\lVert\cdot\right\rVert denotes â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} norm.

3 Theoretical Analysis for I.I.D Case

In this section, similar to most of previous works, we assume that all samples are i.i.d. We discuss two cases, depending on whether sample sizes are balanced in different clients.

Assumption 3.

ğ™iâ€‹jsubscriptğ™ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{Z}_{ij} are i.i.d for all i=1,â€¦,mğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘ši=1,\ldots,m and j=1,â€¦,niğ‘—1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–j=1,\ldots,n_{i}. For any iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j, âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ°,ğ™iâ€‹j)âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ°subscriptğ™ğ‘–ğ‘—\nabla f(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{Z}_{ij}) is sub-exponential with parameter Ïƒğœ\sigma, i.e.

supâ€–ğ¯â€–=1â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[eÎ»â€‹ğ¯Tâ€‹(âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ°,ğ™iâ€‹j))âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°)]â‰¤e12â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹Î»2,Â ifÂ â€‹|Î»|â‰¤1Ïƒformulae-sequencenormğ¯1supremumğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘’ğœ†superscriptğ¯ğ‘‡âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ°subscriptğ™ğ‘–ğ‘—âˆ‡ğ¹ğ°superscriptğ‘’12superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ†2Â ifÂ ğœ†1ğœ\displaystyle\underset{\|\mathbf{v}\|=1}{\sup}\mathbb{E}\left[e^{\lambda\mathbf{v}^{T}(\nabla f(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{Z}_{ij}))-\nabla F(\mathbf{w})}\right]\leq e^{\frac{1}{2}\sigma^{2}\lambda^{2}},\text{ if }|\lambda|\leq\frac{1}{\sigma} (11)

for any vector ğ¯ğ¯\mathbf{v} with âˆ¥ğ¯âˆ¥=1delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ¯1\left\lVert\mathbf{v}\right\rVert=1;

Assumption 3 ensures that with high probability, using the true sample gradients, we are able to identify ğ°âˆ—superscriptğ°\mathbf{w}^{*} defined in (2). Similar assumption was also made in [8, 20].

3.1 Balanced Data

In this case, we assume that ni=N/msubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘šn_{i}=N/m for all iğ‘–i, in which Nğ‘N is the total number of training samples, and mğ‘šm is the number of clients. Here we just denote nğ‘›n as the number of samples per client, and the subscript iğ‘–i is omitted. The analysis here can be simply generalized to the case in which nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} are different but are in the same order, i.e. there exists two constants c1subscriptğ‘1c_{1} and c2subscriptğ‘2c_{2}, such that c1â€‹nâ‰¤niâ‰¤c2â€‹nsubscriptğ‘1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘2ğ‘›c_{1}n\leq n_{i}\leq c_{2}n. Since data sizes are balanced, we set equal thresholds in Huber losses, i.e. Ti=Tsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–ğ‘‡T_{i}=T for all iğ‘–i.

We aim to obtain a bound of âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert, the error of the estimation of global minimizer, that holds with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta. In particular, the following theorem holds. For the sake of simplicity, we state the asymptotic version here, while the finite sample bounds and proofs are shown in the appendix.

Theorem 1.

There exists two constants C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1} and C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2}, if

C1â€‹dnâ€‹lnâ¡NÎ´â‰¤Tâ‰¤C2â€‹dnâ€‹lnâ¡NÎ´,subscriptğ¶1ğ‘‘ğ‘›ğ‘ğ›¿ğ‘‡subscriptğ¶2ğ‘‘ğ‘›ğ‘ğ›¿\displaystyle C_{1}\sqrt{\frac{d}{n}\ln\frac{N}{\delta}}\leq T\leq C_{2}\sqrt{\frac{d}{n}\ln\frac{N}{\delta}}, (12)

then under Assumption 2 and 3, with |â„¬|=Ïµâ€‹mâ„¬italic-Ïµğ‘š|\mathcal{B}|=\epsilon m Byzantine clients, the following equations hold with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta.

(1) (Strong convex) Under Assumption 1(a), if Î·â‰¤1/Lğœ‚1ğ¿\eta\leq 1/L,

âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â‰¤(1âˆ’Ï)tâ€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+2â€‹Î”AÎ¼,delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°superscript1ğœŒğ‘¡delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°2subscriptÎ”ğ´ğœ‡\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq(1-\rho)^{t}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{2\Delta_{A}}{\mu}, (13)

in which Ï=Î·â€‹Î¼/2ğœŒğœ‚ğœ‡2\rho=\eta\mu/2;

(2) (General convex) Under Assumption 1(b), with Î·=1/Lğœ‚1ğ¿\eta=1/L, after tm=(L/Î”A)â€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ¿subscriptÎ”ğ´subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°2t_{m}=(L/\Delta_{A})\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert_{2} steps,

Fâ€‹(ğ°tm)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)â‰¤16â€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â€‹Î”A;ğ¹subscriptğ°subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ¹superscriptğ°16delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°subscriptÎ”ğ´\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t_{m}})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq 16\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\Delta_{A}; (14)

(3) (Non-convex) Under Assumption 1(c), with Î·=1/Lğœ‚1ğ¿\eta=1/L, after tm=(2â€‹L/Î”A2)â€‹(Fâ€‹(ğ°0)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—))subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘š2ğ¿superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ´2ğ¹subscriptğ°0ğ¹superscriptğ°t_{m}=(2L/\Delta_{A}^{2})(F(\mathbf{w}_{0})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})) steps, we have

mint=0,1,â€¦,tmâ€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥â‰¤2â€‹Î”A,ğ‘¡01â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2subscriptÎ”ğ´\displaystyle\underset{t=0,1,\ldots,t_{m}}{\min}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert\leq\sqrt{2}\Delta_{A}, (15)

in which

Î”Aâ‰²(11âˆ’2â€‹Ïµâ€‹Ïµn+1N)â€‹dâ€‹lnâ¡NÎ´.less-than-or-similar-tosubscriptÎ”ğ´112italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµğ‘›1ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ›¿\displaystyle\Delta_{A}\lesssim\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-2\epsilon}}\frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)\sqrt{d\ln\frac{N}{\delta}}. (16)

From (12), the selection of parameter Tğ‘‡T does not rely on the knowledge of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. Moreover, with fixed dğ‘‘d, if Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is small, our error bound O~â€‹(Ïµ/n+1/N)~ğ‘‚italic-Ïµğ‘›1ğ‘\tilde{O}(\epsilon/\sqrt{n}+1/\sqrt{N}) is nearly optimal, since it matches the information-theoretic minimax lower bound up to a logarithm factor [9].

3.2 Unbalanced Data

Now we discuss a more realistic setting, such that nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} are different among clients. In this case, we design an adaptive selection rule of Tisubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–T_{i}. For a benign client Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i} with nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} samples, from central limit theorem, the distance between the gradient vector send to the server decays roughly with the squared root of nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i}, i.e. âˆ¥ğ—iâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ¥âˆ¼d/nisimilar-todelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ°âˆ‡ğ¹ğ°ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–\left\lVert\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\right\rVert\sim\sqrt{d/n_{i}} with high probability. Therefore, if nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} is large and Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i} is benign, then ğ—iâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ°\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w}) should be close to most of other gradient vectors. If ğ—iâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ°\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w}) is far away from others, then client Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i} is highly likely to be Byzantine. However, if nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} is small, even if ğ—iâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ°\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w}) is far away from others, we can not infer that Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i} is Byzantine, since the variance of ğ—iâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ°\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w}) is large even if Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i} is benign. With such intuition, we set Tisubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–T_{i} to be smaller with large nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i}, and vice versa.

To ensure the convergence, both the ratio of attacked clients and the ratio of the samples in attacked clients need to be small. Therefore, we slightly change the definition of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon as the maximum of the fraction of Byzantine clients, and the fraction of samples stored in Byzantine clients, i.e.

Ïµ=maxâ¡{|â„¬|m,âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„¬niN}.italic-Ïµâ„¬ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘–â„¬subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘\displaystyle\epsilon=\max\left\{\frac{|\mathcal{B}|}{m},\frac{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{B}}n_{i}}{N}\right\}. (17)

The theoretical results for unbalanced data is shown in Theorem 2.

Theorem 2.

Let

Ti=T0+Mni,subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‡0ğ‘€subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–\displaystyle T_{i}=T_{0}+\frac{M}{\sqrt{n_{i}}}, (18)

with Mâˆ¼Ïƒâ€‹dâ€‹lnâ¡(N/Î´)similar-toğ‘€ğœğ‘‘ğ‘ğ›¿M\sim\sigma\sqrt{d\ln(N/\delta)}, and

Ïµâ€‹Ïƒâ€‹mâ€‹dNâ€‹lnâ¡NÎ´â‰²T0â‰²Ïƒâ€‹mâ€‹dNâ€‹lnâ¡NÎ´.less-than-or-similar-toitalic-Ïµğœğ‘šğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ›¿subscriptğ‘‡0less-than-or-similar-toğœğ‘šğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ›¿\displaystyle\epsilon\sigma\sqrt{\frac{md}{N}\ln\frac{N}{\delta}}\lesssim T_{0}\lesssim\sigma\sqrt{\frac{md}{N}\ln\frac{N}{\delta}}. (19)

Then under Assumption 2 and 3, the following equations hold for small Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon with probability 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta.

(1) (Strong convex) Under Assumption 1(a), if Î·â‰¤1/Lğœ‚1ğ¿\eta\leq 1/L,

âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â‰¤(1âˆ’Ï)tâ€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+2â€‹Î”AÎ¼,delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°superscript1ğœŒğ‘¡delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°2subscriptÎ”ğ´ğœ‡\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq(1-\rho)^{t}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{2\Delta_{A}}{\mu}, (20)

in which Ï=Î·â€‹Î¼/2ğœŒğœ‚ğœ‡2\rho=\eta\mu/2;

(2) (General convex) Under Assumption 1(b), with Î·=1/Lğœ‚1ğ¿\eta=1/L, after tm=(L/Î”B)â€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ¿subscriptÎ”ğµsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°2t_{m}=(L/\Delta_{B})\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert_{2} steps,

Fâ€‹(ğ°tm)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)â‰¤16â€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â€‹Î”B;ğ¹subscriptğ°subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ¹superscriptğ°16delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°subscriptÎ”ğµ\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t_{m}})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq 16\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\Delta_{B}; (21)

(3) (Non-convex) Under Assumption 1(c), with Î·=1/Lğœ‚1ğ¿\eta=1/L, after tm=(2â€‹L/Î”B2)â€‹(Fâ€‹(ğ°0)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—))subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘š2ğ¿superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğµ2ğ¹subscriptğ°0ğ¹superscriptğ°t_{m}=(2L/\Delta_{B}^{2})(F(\mathbf{w}_{0})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})) steps, we have

mint=0,1,â€¦,tmâ€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥â‰¤2â€‹Î”B,ğ‘¡01â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2subscriptÎ”ğµ\displaystyle\underset{t=0,1,\ldots,t_{m}}{\min}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert\leq\sqrt{2}\Delta_{B}, (22)

in which

Î”Bâ‰²(Ïµ1âˆ’2â€‹Ïµâ€‹mN+1N)â€‹dâ€‹lnâ¡NÎ´.less-than-or-similar-tosubscriptÎ”ğµitalic-Ïµ12italic-Ïµğ‘šğ‘1ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ›¿\displaystyle\Delta_{B}\lesssim\left(\frac{\epsilon}{1-2\epsilon}\sqrt{\frac{m}{N}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)\sqrt{d\ln\frac{N}{\delta}}. (23)

Now we compare (23) with (16). If Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is close to 1/2121/2, then the error is larger with unbalanced data sizes than the balanced case. In particular, the factor 1/(1âˆ’2â€‹Ïµ)112italic-Ïµ1/(1-2\epsilon) in (23) is larger than the factor 1/1âˆ’2â€‹Ïµ112italic-Ïµ1/\sqrt{1-2\epsilon} in (16). However, if Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is small, we can neglect the factor 1/(1âˆ’2â€‹Ïµ)112italic-Ïµ1/(1-2\epsilon), thus the only difference between (23) and (16) is that the first term Ïµ/nitalic-Ïµğ‘›\epsilon/\sqrt{n} in the bracket in (16) is now replaced by Ïµâ€‹m/Nitalic-Ïµğ‘šğ‘\epsilon\sqrt{m/N}. Recall that if samples are evenly distributed, then n=N/mğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘šn=N/m, thus these two bounds are actually of the same order. Therefore, we have shown a somewhat surprising result that the statistical error rate is not affected by the unbalanced allocation of training samples in clients.

4 Theoretical Analysis for Non-I.I.D Case

In this section, we assume that clients are heterogeneous. In particular, suppose that for any ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w}, Î¼iâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ°\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}), i=1,â€¦,mğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘ši=1,\ldots,m are mğ‘šm i.i.d random variables with ğ”¼â€‹[Î¼iâ€‹(ğ°)]=Fâ€‹(ğ°)ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ°ğ¹ğ°\mathbb{E}[\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w})]=F(\mathbf{w}). Furthermore, assume that ğ™iâ€‹jsubscriptğ™ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{Z}_{ij} for j=1,â€¦,niğ‘—1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–j=1,\ldots,n_{i} are conditional independent given Î¼iâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ°\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}), and ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ°,ğ™iâ€‹j)|Î¼iâ€‹(ğ°)]=Î¼iâ€‹(ğ°)ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ°subscriptğ™ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ°subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ°\mathbb{E}[\nabla f(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{Z}_{ij})|\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w})]=\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}). Now we replace Assumption 3 with the following new assumption.

Assumption 4.

(a) Î¼iâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ°\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}) is sub-exponential with respect to âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ‡ğ¹ğ°\nabla F(\mathbf{w}) with parameter ÏƒÎ¼subscriptğœğœ‡\sigma_{\mu}, i.e.

supâˆ¥ğ¯âˆ¥=1â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[eÎ»â€‹ğ¯Tâ€‹(Î¼iâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°))]â‰¤e12â€‹ÏƒÎ¼2â€‹Î»2,Â ifÂ â€‹|Î»|â‰¤1ÏƒÎ¼;formulae-sequencedelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ¯1supremumğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘’ğœ†superscriptğ¯ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ°âˆ‡ğ¹ğ°superscriptğ‘’12superscriptsubscriptğœğœ‡2superscriptğœ†2Â ifÂ ğœ†1subscriptğœğœ‡\displaystyle\underset{\left\lVert\mathbf{v}\right\rVert=1}{\sup}\mathbb{E}\left[e^{\lambda\mathbf{v}^{T}(\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w}))}\right]\leq e^{\frac{1}{2}\sigma_{\mu}^{2}\lambda^{2}},\text{ if }|\lambda|\leq\frac{1}{\sigma_{\mu}}; (24)

(b) ğ™iâ€‹jsubscriptğ™ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{Z}_{ij} is sub-exponential with respect to Î¼iâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ°\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}) with parameter Ïƒğœ\sigma, i.e.

supâˆ¥ğ¯âˆ¥=1â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[eÎ»â€‹ğ¯Tâ€‹(âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ°,ğ™iâ€‹j)âˆ’Î¼iâ€‹(ğ°))]â‰¤e12â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹Î»2,Â ifÂ â€‹|Î»|â‰¤1Ïƒ,formulae-sequencedelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ¯1supremumğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘’ğœ†superscriptğ¯ğ‘‡âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ°subscriptğ™ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ°superscriptğ‘’12superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ†2Â ifÂ ğœ†1ğœ\displaystyle\underset{\left\lVert\mathbf{v}\right\rVert=1}{\sup}\mathbb{E}\left[e^{\lambda\mathbf{v}^{T}(\nabla f(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{Z}_{ij})-\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}))}\right]\leq e^{\frac{1}{2}\sigma^{2}\lambda^{2}},\text{ if }|\lambda|\leq\frac{1}{\sigma}, (25)

in which ğ™iâ€‹jsubscriptğ™ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{Z}_{ij}, j=1,â€¦,niğ‘—1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–j=1,\ldots,n_{i} are conditional i.i.d given Î¼iâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ°\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}).

Assumption 4(a) allows heterogeneous data. However, Î¼iâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ°\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}) follows a sub-exponential distribution with parameter ÏƒÎ¼subscriptğœğœ‡\sigma_{\mu}, thus the distance can not be too large. (b) requires that within each client, ğ™iâ€‹jsubscriptğ™ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{Z}_{ij} is sub-exponential with respect to Î¼iâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ°\mu_{i}(\mathbf{w}) for client iğ‘–i. At the limit of ÏƒÎ¼â†’0â†’subscriptğœğœ‡0\sigma_{\mu}\rightarrow 0, Assumption 4 reduces to Assumption 3. Some existing works assume that the clients are completely different, such as [16], which groups clients into some clusters with inherently different properties. However, we assume that training samples are collected from sources that are only moderately different. The theoretical result is shown as following.

Theorem 3.

Let Ti=T0â€‹a+T0â€‹b+M/nisubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‡0ğ‘subscriptğ‘‡0ğ‘ğ‘€subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–T_{i}=T_{0a}+T_{0b}+M/\sqrt{n_{i}}, with Mâˆ¼Ïƒâ€‹dâ€‹lnâ¡(N/Î´)similar-toğ‘€ğœğ‘‘ğ‘ğ›¿M\sim\sigma\sqrt{d\ln(N/\delta)}, and

Ïµâ€‹Ïƒâ€‹(mâ€‹d/N)â€‹lnâ¡(N/Î´)â‰²T0â€‹aâ‰²Ïƒâ€‹(mâ€‹d/N)â€‹lnâ¡(N/Î´),less-than-or-similar-toitalic-Ïµğœğ‘šğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ›¿subscriptğ‘‡0ğ‘less-than-or-similar-toğœğ‘šğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ›¿\displaystyle\epsilon\sigma\sqrt{(md/N)\ln(N/\delta)}\lesssim T_{0a}\lesssim\sigma\sqrt{(md/N)\ln(N/\delta)}, (26)

and

T0â€‹bâˆ¼Ïƒâ€‹(d/N)â€‹lnâ¡(N/Î´),similar-tosubscriptğ‘‡0ğ‘ğœğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ›¿\displaystyle T_{0b}\sim\sigma\sqrt{(d/N)\ln(N/\delta)}, (27)

then under Assumption 2 and 4, the following equations holds with probability at least 1âˆ’2â€‹Î´12ğ›¿1-2\delta.

(1) (Strong convex) Under Assumption 1(a), with Î·â‰¤1/Lğœ‚1ğ¿\eta\leq 1/L,

âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â‰¤(1âˆ’Ï)tâ€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+2â€‹Î”CÎ¼,delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°superscript1ğœŒğ‘¡delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°2subscriptÎ”ğ¶ğœ‡\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq(1-\rho)^{t}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{2\Delta_{C}}{\mu}, (28)

in which Ï=Î·â€‹Î¼/2ğœŒğœ‚ğœ‡2\rho=\eta\mu/2;

(2) (General convex) Under Assumption 1(b), with Î·=1/Lğœ‚1ğ¿\eta=1/L, after tm=(L/Î”C)â€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ¿subscriptÎ”ğ¶subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°2t_{m}=(L/\Delta_{C})\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert_{2} steps,

Fâ€‹(ğ°tm)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)â‰¤16â€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â€‹Î”C;ğ¹subscriptğ°subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ¹superscriptğ°16delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°subscriptÎ”ğ¶\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t_{m}})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq 16\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\Delta_{C}; (29)

(3) (Non-convex) Under Assumption 1(c), with Î·=1/Lğœ‚1ğ¿\eta=1/L, after tm=(2â€‹L/Î”C2)â€‹(Fâ€‹(ğ°0)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—))subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘š2ğ¿superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ¶2ğ¹subscriptğ°0ğ¹superscriptğ°t_{m}=(2L/\Delta_{C}^{2})(F(\mathbf{w}_{0})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})) steps, we have

mint=0,1,â€¦,tmâ€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥â‰¤2â€‹Î”C,ğ‘¡01â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2subscriptÎ”ğ¶\displaystyle\underset{t=0,1,\ldots,t_{m}}{\min}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert\leq\sqrt{2}\Delta_{C}, (30)

in which

Î”CsubscriptÎ”ğ¶\displaystyle\Delta_{C} â‰²less-than-or-similar-to\displaystyle\lesssim (Ïµ1âˆ’2â€‹Ïµâ€‹mN+1N+ÏƒÎ¼â€‹âˆ‘i=1mni2N)â€‹dâ€‹lnâ¡NÎ´+Ïµâ€‹ÏƒÎ¼â€‹dâ€‹lnâ¡NÎ´.italic-Ïµ12italic-Ïµğ‘šğ‘1ğ‘subscriptğœğœ‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–2ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ›¿italic-Ïµsubscriptğœğœ‡ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ›¿\displaystyle\left(\frac{\epsilon}{1-2\epsilon}\sqrt{\frac{m}{N}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}+\frac{\sigma_{\mu}\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{m}n_{i}^{2}}}{N}\right)\sqrt{d\ln\frac{N}{\delta}}+\epsilon\sigma_{\mu}d\ln\frac{N}{\delta}. (31)

5 Implementation

Our design follows the Weiszfeldâ€™s algorithm for geometric median [18]. Suppose there are mğ‘šm vectors, ğ—1,â€¦,ğ—msubscriptğ—1â€¦subscriptğ—ğ‘š\mathbf{X}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{X}_{m}. Define

ğœ=argâ¡minğ‘ â€‹âˆ‘i=1mÏ•iâ€‹(âˆ¥ğ¬âˆ’ğ—iâˆ¥)ğœğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ¬subscriptğ—ğ‘–\displaystyle\mathbf{c}=\underset{s}{\arg\min}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\phi_{i}(\left\lVert\mathbf{s}-\mathbf{X}_{i}\right\rVert) (32)

as the center that minimizes the multi-dimensional Huber loss, in which Ï•isubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–\phi_{i} is defined in (10). Suppose that the algorithm starts from ğœ0subscriptğœ0\mathbf{c}_{0}. Then the update rule is

ğœk+1=âˆ‘i=1mminâ¡{1,Tiâˆ¥ğœkâˆ’ğ—iâˆ¥}â€‹ğ—iâˆ‘i=1mminâ¡{1,Tiâˆ¥ğœkâˆ’ğ—iâˆ¥}.subscriptğœğ‘˜1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘š1subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğœğ‘˜subscriptğ—ğ‘–subscriptğ—ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘š1subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğœğ‘˜subscriptğ—ğ‘–\displaystyle\mathbf{c}_{k+1}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{m}\min\left\{1,\frac{T_{i}}{\left\lVert\mathbf{c}_{k}-\mathbf{X}_{i}\right\rVert}\right\}\mathbf{X}_{i}}{\sum_{i=1}^{m}\min\left\{1,\frac{T_{i}}{\left\lVert\mathbf{c}_{k}-\mathbf{X}_{i}\right\rVert}\right\}}. (33)

Our algorithm repeats (33) until convergence. Similar to Weiszfeldâ€™s algorithm, despite the fast convergence in almost all practical cases, it is not theoretically guaranteed in general. In section 8 in [21], it is shown that under some assumptions, an estimate of geometric median with Weiszfeldâ€™s algorithm with error tolerance Ï„ğœ\tau needs Oâ€‹(1/Ï„)ğ‘‚1ğœO(1/\tau) steps. With minor modification, the analysis in [21] also holds for our new algorithm (33). Moreover, from (33), each step requires Oâ€‹(mâ€‹d)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘‘O(md) time, thus the overall time complexity is Oâ€‹(mâ€‹d/Ï„)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘‘ğœO(md/\tau).

In the future, it is possible to extend some recent works on geometric median, such as [22, 23] to improve the update rule (33) for multi-dimensional Huber loss minimization.

6 Comparison with Related Work

Now we compare our results with several existing popular approaches, including Krum [7], geometric median-of-means [8] (GMM), coordinate-wise median [9] (CWM), coordinate-wise trimmed mean [9] (CWTM), and recent methods based on high dimensional robust statistics [24, 19] (HDRS). To begin with, we consider the i.i.d case. In particular, we compare the following five aspects listed as following:

  • â€¢

    Whether the method relies on precise knowledge of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon;

  • â€¢

    Under sub-exponential and strong convex assumption, with sufficiently large number of iterations tğ‘¡t, whether the statistical error rate of âˆ¥ğ°^âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥^ğ°superscriptğ°\left\lVert\hat{\mathbf{w}}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert is optimal (or nearly optimal up to a logarithm factor) in Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. Here the optimal rate is Ïµ/n+d/Nitalic-Ïµğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘\epsilon/\sqrt{n}+\sqrt{d/N} [25, 9];

  • â€¢

    Whether the performance is good if Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is close to 1/2121/2. In particular, whether error blows up by a factor of no more than 1/1âˆ’2â€‹Ïµ112italic-Ïµ1/\sqrt{1-2\epsilon}, as is shown in (16);

  • â€¢

    Whether the time complexity of aggregator is linear or nearly linear, i.e. Oâ€‹(m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šO(m) or Oâ€‹(mâ€‹logâ¡m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘šO(m\log m);

  • â€¢

    Whether the error rate is optimal in dimensionality dğ‘‘d;

The results are shown in Table 1, in which the five aspects mentioned above correspond to its five columns.

For the first aspect, only coordinate-wise median and our method do not rely on precise knowledge of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. For other methods, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon significantly affects the parameter selection. For example, coordinate-wise trimmed mean need to set the trim threshold to be Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon in both sides. However, it is quite unlikely to have exact knowledge of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon in practice. If an upper bound Î±ğ›¼\alpha is known, such that Ïµ<Î±italic-Ïµğ›¼\epsilon<\alpha, then Î±ğ›¼\alpha can be used to set the parameter, but the accuracy will be sacrificed. Secondly, for optimal dependence in Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, Krum is not guaranteed to converge globally. Coordinate-wise median is not optimal if nâ‰²mless-than-or-similar-toğ‘›ğ‘šn\lesssim m. Geometric median-of-mean only has a O~â€‹(Ïµâ€‹d/n)~ğ‘‚italic-Ïµğ‘‘ğ‘›\tilde{O}(\sqrt{\epsilon d/n}) dependence. Thirdly, for the performance with Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon close to 1/2121/2, coordinate-wise trimmed mean is not optimal. In particular, the error rate Î”Câ€‹Wâ€‹Tâ€‹MsubscriptÎ”ğ¶ğ‘Šğ‘‡ğ‘€\Delta_{CWTM}, which plays the same role as Î”AsubscriptÎ”ğ´\Delta_{A} in Theorem 1, is

Î”Câ€‹Wâ€‹Tâ€‹M=O~â€‹(d1âˆ’2â€‹Ïµâ€‹(Ïµn+1N)),subscriptÎ”ğ¶ğ‘Šğ‘‡ğ‘€~ğ‘‚ğ‘‘12italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµğ‘›1ğ‘\displaystyle\Delta_{CWTM}=\tilde{O}\left(\frac{d}{1-2\epsilon}\left(\frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)\right), (34)

which blows up by a factor of 1/(1âˆ’2â€‹Ïµ)112italic-Ïµ1/(1-2\epsilon), higher than 1/1âˆ’2â€‹Ïµ112italic-Ïµ1/\sqrt{1-2\epsilon}. Intuitively, with Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon close to 1/2121/2, coordinate-wise trimmed mean is not efficient because it removes most of samples, thus somewhat wastes the data. For the fourth column in Table 1, the time complexity has been discussed in previous section.

The only drawback of our method is that the dependence on dğ‘‘d is not optimal. In recent years, there are some new proposed methods for high dimensional robust mean estimation [26, 27, 28]. These methods can be used as the aggregator function in federated learning [29, 24, 19, 30], so that the dependence on dğ‘‘d becomes optimal. However, the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon dependence is Ïµitalic-Ïµ\sqrt{\epsilon}, which is optimal only if we merely require the covariance matrix to have bounded operator norms. Under a more restrictive sub-exponential assumption, the convergence can not be further improved. Moreover, the time complexity is much higher.

One may wonder if it is possible to design an aggregator that satisfy all of the five properties listed in Table 1. However, [25] has shown that for robust mean estimation problem, as long as Pâ‰ Nâ€‹Pğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ƒP\neq NP, under sub-exponential assumption, polynomial time complexity, optimal dependence in Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, and constant factor in dğ‘‘d are three goals that can not be achieved together. Since FL relies on robust mean estimation of gradient vectors as the aggregator function, we conjecture that it is impossible to satisfy all five properties in Table 1.

Right now we have compared our results with existing methods under i.i.d assumptions. There are also some related work focusing on non-i.i.d cases, but the assumptions are crucially different. For example, [14] proposed RSA. Instead of designing a gradient aggregator, [14] conducts model aggregation, which tries to reach a consensus between different models. This method is suitable for the cases in which the distributions in clients are significantly different. However, under the i.i.d limit, [14] does not have bounds comparable to existing methods under i.i.d assumption.

7 Numerical Results

This section shows numerical experiments. Despite the fact that our method has the advantage of not relying on knowledge of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, in this section, we just assume that all baseline methods know Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon exactly, including Krum, GMM, CWM and CWTM mentioned in the previous section. Parameters of these methods are all optimally selected with the precise knowledge of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. If Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is unknown, then the advantage of our method should be larger than what is described in this section. The detailed algorithms and parameter selection rules are:

Krum [7]: Let k=mâˆ’qâˆ’2ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘2k=m-q-2, with qğ‘q being the number of Byzantine clients, then Krum picks iâˆ—superscriptğ‘–i^{*} as

iâˆ—=argâ¡miniâˆˆ[m]â€‹âˆ‘j=1kâˆ¥ğ—iâˆ’ğ—i(j)âˆ¥2,superscriptğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘˜superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ—ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ‘—2\displaystyle i^{*}=\underset{i\in[m]}{\arg\min}\sum_{j=1}^{k}\left\lVert\mathbf{X}_{i}-\mathbf{X}_{i}^{(j)}\right\rVert^{2}, (35)

in which ğ—i(j)superscriptsubscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{X}_{i}^{(j)} is the jğ‘—j-th nearest neighbor of ğ—isubscriptğ—ğ‘–\mathbf{X}_{i} among {ğ—1,â€¦,ğ—m}subscriptğ—1â€¦subscriptğ—ğ‘š\{\mathbf{X}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{X}_{m}\}. Then

gKâ€‹râ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹(ğ°)=Xiâ£âˆ—.subscriptğ‘”ğ¾ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘šğ°subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–\displaystyle g_{Krum}(\mathbf{w})=X_{i*}. (36)

Geometric median-of-mean (GMM) [8]. It randomly divides mğ‘šm vectors from clients into bğ‘b batches, and then calculate geometric median of the mean gradients of these batches:

gGâ€‹Mâ€‹Mâ€‹(ğ°)=argâ¡minğ‘ â€‹âˆ‘j=1bâˆ¥ğ¬âˆ’1|Aj|â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆAjğ—iâˆ¥.subscriptğ‘”ğºğ‘€ğ‘€ğ°ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ¬1subscriptğ´ğ‘—subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ´ğ‘—subscriptğ—ğ‘–\displaystyle g_{GMM}(\mathbf{w})=\underset{s}{\arg\min}\sum_{j=1}^{b}\left\lVert\mathbf{s}-\frac{1}{|A_{j}|}\sum_{i\in A_{j}}\mathbf{X}_{i}\right\rVert. (37)

In our experiments, following [8], we set b=2â€‹q+1ğ‘2ğ‘1b=2q+1, in which qğ‘q is the number of Byzantine clients.

Coordinate-wise median (CWM)[9]. This is an aggregation rule that calculates the element-wise median of vectors ğ—1,â€¦,ğ—msubscriptğ—1â€¦subscriptğ—ğ‘š\mathbf{X}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{X}_{m}.

Coordinate-wise trimmed mean (CWTM)[9]. We assume that Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is known. In each dimension, CWTM removes the largest and smallest Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon fraction of values and then calculate the element-wise mean.

Ideally, robustness against Byzantine failure needs to be tested using optimal attack strategies. However, the optimization problems are hard to solve. In this section, we use four attack strategies. One of them is a simple sign-flip attack, which flips the sign of gradient vectors. Other three are some approximate strategies that are tailored to specific aggregators, including Krum Attack (KA) and Trimmed Mean Attack (TMA) described in [31] that are nearly optimal for Krum and CWTM, respectively. Moreover, for a fair comparison, we have designed an attack strategy for our new proposed method, called Huber Loss Minimization Attack (HLMA). Here we provide the details of all these attacks.

Denote

g0â€‹(ğ°t)=1mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1mğ†iâ€‹(ğ°t),subscriptğ‘”0subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptğ†ğ‘–subscriptğ°ğ‘¡\displaystyle g_{0}(\mathbf{w}_{t})=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\mathbf{G}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}), (38)

with

ğ†iâ€‹(ğ°t)=1niâ€‹âˆ‘j=1niâˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ°t,ğ™iâ€‹j).subscriptğ†ğ‘–subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğ™ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle\mathbf{G}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t},\mathbf{Z}_{ij}). (39)

Let ğ¬t=signâ¡(g0â€‹(ğ°t))subscriptğ¬ğ‘¡signsubscriptğ‘”0subscriptğ°ğ‘¡\mathbf{s}_{t}=\operatorname{sign}(g_{0}(\mathbf{w}_{t})) to be the element-wise sign of g0â€‹(ğ°t)subscriptğ‘”0subscriptğ°ğ‘¡g_{0}(\mathbf{w}_{t}). We solve the following optimization problem:

maxÏ€Aâ€‹ğ¬Tâ€‹(g0â€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’gâ€‹(ğ°t)),subscriptğœ‹ğ´superscriptğ¬ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘”0subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡\displaystyle\underset{\pi_{A}}{\max}\mathbf{s}^{T}(g_{0}(\mathbf{w}_{t})-g(\mathbf{w}_{t})), (40)

in which Ï€Asubscriptğœ‹ğ´\pi_{A} is the attack strategy. Such formulation follows [31]. The intuition is to make the aggregated gradient should be as far away from the ground truth âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}) (approximated by g0(ğ°t))g_{0}(\mathbf{w}_{t}))) as possible. Moreover, in each coordinate, it would be better if gâ€‹(ğ°t)ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡g(\mathbf{w}_{t}) is moved towards the opposite direction to g0â€‹(ğ°t)subscriptğ‘”0subscriptğ°ğ‘¡g_{0}(\mathbf{w}_{t}), such that the model updates along a wrong direction. Our design of Krum attack and Trimmed mean attack follows [31].

Krum Attack (KA). KA maximizes Î»ğœ†\lambda, such that with all attacked samples placed at g0â€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Î»â€‹ğ¬subscriptğ‘”0subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ†ğ¬g_{0}(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\lambda\mathbf{s}, Krum selects one of these attacked samples as the aggregated gradient according to (35). Practically, we set Î»=1ğœ†1\lambda=1 first, and then repeat with Î»â†Î»/2â†ğœ†ğœ†2\lambda\leftarrow\lambda/2 until Krum selects one of attacked samples, or Î»<10âˆ’4ğœ†superscript104\lambda<10^{-4}.

Trimmed Mean Attack (TMA). Denote Xiâ€‹t,jsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘—X_{it,j} as the jğ‘—j-th element of ğ—iâ€‹jsubscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{X}_{ij}, and

Giâ€‹jâ€‹(ğ°t)=1niâ€‹âˆ‘j=1niâˆ‚jfâ€‹(ğ°t,ğ™iâ€‹j).subscriptğºğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘—ğ‘“subscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğ™ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle G_{ij}(\mathbf{w}_{t})=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\partial_{j}f(\mathbf{w}_{t},\mathbf{Z}_{ij}). (41)

Then the attack strategy is

Xiâ€‹t,j={maxiâˆˆ[m]â€‹Giâ€‹jâ€‹(ğ°t)ifs=âˆ’1miniâˆˆ[m]â€‹Giâ€‹jâ€‹(ğ°t)ifs=1.subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘—casesğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘šsubscriptğºğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ifğ‘ 1ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘šsubscriptğºğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ifğ‘ 1\displaystyle X_{it,j}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ccc}\underset{i\in[m]}{\max}G_{ij}(\mathbf{w}_{t})&\text{if}&s=-1\\ \underset{i\in[m]}{\min}G_{ij}(\mathbf{w}_{t})&\text{if}&s=1.\end{array}\right. (44)

It has been discussed in [31] that the TMA is also optimal for coordinate-wise median.

Huber Loss Minimization Attack (HLMA). We let

Xiâ€‹t,j={Giâ€‹jâ€‹(ğ°t)+Tdifs=âˆ’1Giâ€‹jâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Tdifs=1.subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘—casessubscriptğºğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘‡ğ‘‘ifğ‘ 1subscriptğºğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘‡ğ‘‘ifğ‘ 1\displaystyle X_{it,j}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ccc}G_{ij}(\mathbf{w}_{t})+\frac{T}{\sqrt{d}}&\text{if}&s=-1\\ G_{ij}(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\frac{T}{\sqrt{d}}&\text{if}&s=1.\end{array}\right. (47)

In Section 7.1 and 7.2, we show simple experiments on some synthesized data and MNIST data, respectively. In these two sections, samples are i.i.d and data allocation is balanced.

7.1 Synthesized Data

To begin with, we run experiments with distributed linear regression. The model is

Vj=âŸ¨ğ”j,ğ°âˆ—âŸ©+Wj,subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘—subscriptğ”ğ‘—superscriptğ°subscriptğ‘Šğ‘—\displaystyle V_{j}=\langle\mathbf{U}_{j},\mathbf{w}^{*}\rangle+W_{j}, (48)

in which ğ”j,ğ°âˆ—âˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ”ğ‘—superscriptğ°superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{U}_{j},\mathbf{w}^{*}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, with ğ°âˆ—superscriptğ°\mathbf{w}^{*} being the true parameter, and Wjsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘—W_{j} is the noise following standard normal distribution. In this experiment, we set d=50ğ‘‘50d=50. Firstly, we generate all elements of ğ°âˆ—superscriptğ°\mathbf{w}^{*} from distribution ğ’©â€‹(0,1)ğ’©01\mathcal{N}(0,1). We then obtain N=10,000ğ‘10000N=10,000 samples (ğ”j,Vj)subscriptğ”ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘—(\mathbf{U}_{j},V_{j}), j=1,â€¦,Nğ‘—1â€¦ğ‘j=1,\ldots,N. These samples are evenly divided into m=500ğ‘š500m=500 clients. For baseline methods including Krum, GMM, CWTM, the parameters are all set optimally, according to the statements at the beginning of Section 7. Our new Huber loss minimization approach uses T=1ğ‘‡1T=1 for all clients. We run 200200200 iterations in total, with learning rate Î·=0.02ğœ‚0.02\eta=0.02. The results are shown in Figure 1 for all four attack strategies mentioned above, in which we plot the square root of the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} regression loss against the number of iterations.

From Figure 1, it can be observed that our new method (red solid curve) works well for all four types of attacks, even with HLMA that is specifically designed for our method. On the contrary, from Figure 1 (b), Krum aggregator (blue dotted curve) fails under KA that is tailored to Krum. Moreover, (c) shows that under TMA which is designed for coordinate-wise trimmed mean, GMM and CWTM (dashed curves with orange and purple colors, respectively) perform significantly worse than our method. CWM appears to be robust, but the performance is not as good as our approach in general.

7.2 Real data

Now we use MNIST dataset [32], which has 60,0006000060,000 images of handwritten digits for training, and 12,0001200012,000 images for testing. The sizes of these images are 28Ã—28282828\times 28. In this experiment, we use a neural network with one hidden layer between input and output. The size of hidden layer is 323232. Training samples are evenly allocated into m=500ğ‘š500m=500 clients. We set T=0.2ğ‘‡0.2T=0.2 here. The results with Ïµ=0.2italic-Ïµ0.2\epsilon=0.2 is shown in Figure 2, in which we plot the curve of accuracy on the test data against the number of iterations.

Similar to synthesized data, experiments on MNIST show that our new method outperforms other methods. Krum is still highly susceptible to KA. CWM and CWTM appear to be only slightly worse than our method.

Now we increase Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon to 0.40.40.4. Other settings remain unchanged. This experiment shows the performance when Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is close to 1/2121/2. The results are shown in Figure 3.

Our method still exhibits desirable performance, even under HLMA designed specifically for ourselves. Krum works relatively well under sign-flip, TMA and HLMA, but fails under KA. The performance of GMM is relatively well for Ïµ=0.4italic-Ïµ0.4\epsilon=0.4. As has been discussed earlier, the drawback of GMM is the suboptimal statistical rate on Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, which is serious for small Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. However, when Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is close to 1/2121/2, this disadvantage becomes much less obvious. Moreover, under TMA and HLMA, the performance of coordinate-wise methods, including CWM and CWTM become significantly worse, especially the latter. This phenomenon agrees with the theoretical analysis, since in section 6, we have discussed that CWTM has suboptimal rate with Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon close to 1/2121/2.

7.3 Unbalanced sample allocation

We then evaluate the adaptive selection rule (18) for unbalanced data. In this experiment, samples are still allocated in different clients randomly, but the sample sizes in different clients are no longer equal.

In this experiment, we use the following allocation rule.

(1) Randomly shuffle training samples. Denote the indices of samples after shuffling as 0,1,â€¦,Nâˆ’101â€¦ğ‘10,1,\ldots,N-1;

(2) Generate mâˆ’1ğ‘š1m-1 indices randomly from {0,â€¦,Nâˆ’1}0â€¦ğ‘1\{0,\ldots,N-1\} without replacement;

(3) Sort these mâˆ’1ğ‘š1m-1 indices in ascending order. Denote the results as b1,â€¦,bmâˆ’1subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘š1b_{1},\ldots,b_{m-1}, such that b1<b2<â€¦<bmâˆ’1subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘š1b_{1}<b_{2}<\ldots<b_{m-1};

(4) Let b0=0subscriptğ‘00b_{0}=0, bm=Nsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘b_{m}=N. Allocate samples with biâ‰¤jâ‰¤bi+1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1b_{i}\leq j\leq b_{i+1} to client iğ‘–i.

It can be shown that with increase of Nğ‘N, the ratio of samples in each client follows Beta distribution ğ”¹â€‹(1,m)ğ”¹1ğ‘š\mathbb{B}(1,m).

We use Ti=2/nisubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–2subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–T_{i}=2/\sqrt{n_{i}} as the threshold of each clients. Other settings remain the same as previous experiments. For simplicity, we only show the result with HLMA in Figure 4.

The result shows that with unbalanced data and our adaptive choice of Tisubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–T_{i}, the advantage of our method becomes more obvious, especially for MNIST data. The comparison of Figure 4(b) with Figure 2(d) shows that our method achieves nearly the same performance as the balanced case, while other methods are somewhat negatively affected by the unbalanced data allocation.

7.4 Heterogeneous Data

Finally, we show the robustness of our proposed method for non-i.i.d data. In particular, we make clients to be heterogeneous. We make some adjustment to the original linear model (48), such that in different machines, ğ°âˆ—superscriptğ°\mathbf{w}^{*} are slightly different:

Vj=âŸ¨ğ”j,ğ°âˆ—+ğš«ğ°â€‹(i)âŸ©+Wjsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘—subscriptğ”ğ‘—superscriptğ°subscriptğš«ğ°ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Šğ‘—\displaystyle V_{j}=\langle\mathbf{U}_{j},\mathbf{w}^{*}+\mathbf{\Delta}_{\mathbf{w}}(i)\rangle+W_{j} (49)

for all sample jğ‘—j stored in client iğ‘–i. Î”ğ°â€‹(i)subscriptÎ”ğ°ğ‘–\Delta_{\mathbf{w}}(i) is the additional weight for client iğ‘–i. We let each component of Î”ğ°â€‹(i)subscriptÎ”ğ°ğ‘–\Delta_{\mathbf{w}}(i) follows distribution ğ’©â€‹(0,0.2)ğ’©00.2\mathcal{N}(0,0.2). Under this setting, conditional on Î”ğ°â€‹(i)subscriptÎ”ğ°ğ‘–\Delta_{\mathbf{w}}(i), samples within each clients are i.i.d. However, they are no longer i.i.d between different clients. The results are shown in Figure 5, in which we fix Ïµ=0.2italic-Ïµ0.2\epsilon=0.2 here.

According to Figure 5, with heterogeneous clients, our method still exhibits advantage compared to existing ones.

8 Conclusion

In this paper, we have proposed a novel approach for Byzantine robust federated learning based on Huber loss minimization. Theoretical analyses have been conducted under the initial i.i.d assumption with balanced data, and subsequently extended to unbalanced and heterogeneous scenarios. Our method offers several advantages over existing approaches, including optimal statistical rate with fixed dimension, convenient selection of parameters without knowledge of Byzantine fraction Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, and suitability for clients with unbalanced data. Furthermore, we have presented an algorithm to implement the multi-dimensional Huber loss minimization. The effectiveness of our approach is validated by numerical experiments. There are several possible directions for further improvements in the future. For example, pre-processing by filtering some obvious outliers may help to reduce the effect of Byzantine clients. Moreover, it is also worthwhile to consider one-round or multi-round robust algorithms to reduce the communication cost.

  • [24] V.Â Shejwalkar and A.Â Houmansadr, â€œManipulating the byzantine: Optimizing model poisoning attacks and defenses for federated learning,â€ in 28th Annual Network and Distributed System Security Symposium, 2021, The Internet Society, 2021.
  • [25] S.Â B. Hopkins and J.Â Li, â€œHow hard is robust mean estimation?,â€ in Conference on Learning Theory, vol.Â 99, pp.Â 1649â€“1682, June 2019.
  • [26] I.Â Diakonikolas, G.Â Kamath, D.Â M. Kane, J.Â Li, A.Â Moitra, and A.Â Stewart, â€œRobust estimators in high dimensions without the computational intractability,â€ in 57th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science, pp.Â 655â€“664, 2016.
  • [27] I.Â Diakonikolas, G.Â Kamath, D.Â M. Kane, J.Â Li, A.Â Moitra, and A.Â Stewart, â€œBeing robust (in high dimensions) can be practical,â€ in International Conference on Machine Learning, pp.Â 999â€“1008, 2017.
  • [28] I.Â Diakonikolas, D.Â Kane, D.Â Kongsgaard, J.Â Li, and K.Â Tian, â€œList-decodable mean estimation in nearly-pca time,â€ in Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems, vol.Â 34, pp.Â 10195â€“10208, 2021.
  • [29] L.Â Su and J.Â Xu, â€œSecuring distributed machine learning in high dimensions,â€ arXiv preprint arXiv:1804.10140, pp.Â 1536â€“1233, 2018.
  • [30] P.Â Zhao and Z.Â Wan, â€œHigh dimensional distributed gradient descent with arbitrary number of byzantine attackers,â€ arXiv preprint arXiv:2307.13352, 2023.
  • [31] M.Â Fang, X.Â Cao, J.Â Jia, and N.Â Gong, â€œLocal model poisoning attacks to byzantine-robust federated learning,â€ in 29th USENIX security symposium (USENIX Security 20), pp.Â 1605â€“1622, 2020.
  • [32] Y.Â LeCun, â€œThe mnist database of handwritten digits,â€ http://yann. lecun. com/exdb/mnist/, 1998.
  • [33] R.Â Vershynin, â€œIntroduction to the non-asymptotic analysis of random matrices,â€ arXiv preprint arXiv:1011.3027, 2010.

Appendix A Common Lemmas on Convergence

Recall that the aggregator function is defined as

gâ€‹(ğ°t)=argâ¡minğ‘ â€‹âˆ‘i=1mniâ€‹Ï•iâ€‹(âˆ¥ğ¬âˆ’ğ—iâ€‹tâˆ¥).ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ¬subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ‘¡\displaystyle g(\mathbf{w}_{t})=\underset{s}{\arg\min}\sum_{i=1}^{m}n_{i}\phi_{i}(\left\lVert\mathbf{s}-\mathbf{X}_{it}\right\rVert). (50)

Now we generalize the definition above to arbitrary ğ°âˆˆğ’²ğ°ğ’²\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W}:

gâ€‹(ğ°)=argâ¡minğ‘ â€‹âˆ‘i=1mniâ€‹Ï•iâ€‹(âˆ¥ğ¬âˆ’ğ—iâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ¥),ğ‘”ğ°ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ¬subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ°\displaystyle g(\mathbf{w})=\underset{s}{\arg\min}\sum_{i=1}^{m}n_{i}\phi_{i}(\left\lVert\mathbf{s}-\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w})\right\rVert), (51)

in which ğ—iâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ°\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w}) denotes the signal from client iğ‘–i, if the master broadcasts ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w}. In particular,

ğ—iâ€‹(ğ°)={ğ†iâ€‹(ğ°)ifiâˆ‰â„¬â‹†ifiâˆˆâ„¬,subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ°casessubscriptğ†ğ‘–ğ°ifğ‘–â„¬â‹†ifğ‘–â„¬\displaystyle\mathbf{X}_{i}(\mathbf{w})=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ccc}\mathbf{G}_{i}(\mathbf{w})&\text{if}&i\notin\mathcal{B}\\ \star&\text{if}&i\in\mathcal{B},\end{array}\right. (54)

with

ğ†iâ€‹(ğ°)=1niâ€‹âˆ‘j=1niâˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ°,ğ™iâ€‹j).subscriptğ†ğ‘–ğ°1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ°subscriptğ™ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle\mathbf{G}_{i}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\nabla f(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{Z}_{ij}). (55)

Define

Î”=supÏ€Aâ€‹supğ°âˆˆğ’²â€‹âˆ¥gâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ¥Î”subscriptğœ‹ğ´supremumğ°ğ’²supremumdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘”ğ°âˆ‡ğ¹ğ°\displaystyle\Delta=\underset{\pi_{A}}{\sup}\underset{\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W}}{\sup}\left\lVert g(\mathbf{w})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\right\rVert (56)

as the supremum error of gradient aggregator, in which Ï€Asubscriptğœ‹ğ´\pi_{A} stands for the strategy of the adversary.

Then we show the following lemmas.

Lemma 1.

(Strong convex Fğ¹F) If Fğ¹F is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strong convex and Lğ¿L-smooth, ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W} is a convex set, and ğ°âˆ—âˆˆğ’²superscriptğ°ğ’²\mathbf{w}^{*}\in\mathcal{W}, then with Î·â‰¤1/Lğœ‚1ğ¿\eta\leq 1/L,

âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â‰¤(1âˆ’Ï)tâ€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+2â€‹Î”Î¼,delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°superscript1ğœŒğ‘¡delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°2Î”ğœ‡\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq(1-\rho)^{t}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{2\Delta}{\mu}, (57)

with

Ï=12â€‹Î·â€‹Î¼.ğœŒ12ğœ‚ğœ‡\displaystyle\rho=\frac{1}{2}\eta\mu. (58)
Proof.

The proof is shown in Section A.1. âˆ

Lemma 2.

(General convex Fğ¹F) If Fğ¹F is convex and Lğ¿L-smooth, and

ğ’²={ğ°|âˆ¥ğ°âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â‰¤2â€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥},ğ’²conditional-setğ°delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ°superscriptğ°2delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°\displaystyle\mathcal{W}=\{\mathbf{w}|\left\lVert\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq 2\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\}, (59)

then with Î·=1/Lğœ‚1ğ¿\eta=1/L, after tm=(L/Î”)â€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ¿Î”subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°2t_{m}=(L/\Delta)\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert_{2} steps,

Fâ€‹(ğ°tm)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)â‰¤16â€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â€‹Î”.ğ¹subscriptğ°subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ¹superscriptğ°16delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°Î”\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t_{m}})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq 16\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\Delta. (60)
Proof.

The proof is shown in Section A.2. âˆ

Lemma 3.

(Non-convex Fğ¹F) If Fğ¹F is Lğ¿L-smooth, âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ¥â‰¤Mdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹ğ°ğ‘€\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\right\rVert\leq M for all ğ°âˆˆğ’²ğ°ğ’²\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W}, and

ğ’²={ğ°|âˆ¥ğ°âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â‰¤2Î”2â€‹(M+Î”)â€‹(Fâ€‹(ğ°0)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—))},ğ’²conditional-setğ°delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ°superscriptğ°2superscriptÎ”2ğ‘€Î”ğ¹subscriptğ°0ğ¹superscriptğ°\displaystyle\mathcal{W}=\left\{\mathbf{w}|\left\lVert\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq\frac{2}{\Delta^{2}}(M+\Delta)(F(\mathbf{w}_{0})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*}))\right\}, (61)

then with Î·=1/Lğœ‚1ğ¿\eta=1/L and

tm=2â€‹LÎ”2â€‹(Fâ€‹(ğ°0)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)),subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘š2ğ¿superscriptÎ”2ğ¹subscriptğ°0ğ¹superscriptğ°\displaystyle t_{m}=\frac{2L}{\Delta^{2}}(F(\mathbf{w}_{0})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})), (62)

we have

mint=0,1,â€¦,tmâ€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥â‰¤2â€‹Î”.ğ‘¡01â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2Î”\displaystyle\underset{t=0,1,\ldots,t_{m}}{\min}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert\leq\sqrt{2}\Delta. (63)
Proof.

The proof is shown in Section A.3. âˆ

A.1 Proof of Lemma 1

âˆ¥ğ°t+1âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1superscriptğ°\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t+1}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert =\displaystyle= âˆ¥Î ğ’²â€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t))âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptÎ ğ’²subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°\displaystyle\left\lVert\Pi_{\mathcal{W}}(\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t}))-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert (64)
â‰¤(a)ğ‘\displaystyle\overset{(a)}{\leq} âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert
â‰¤\displaystyle\leq âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+Î·â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’gâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°ğœ‚delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\eta\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-g(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert
â‰¤(b)ğ‘\displaystyle\overset{(b)}{\leq} âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+Î·â€‹Î”,delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°ğœ‚Î”\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\eta\Delta,

in which (a) uses the assumption that ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W} is a convex set, which was made in the statement of Lemma 1. (b) uses (56). For the first term,

âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2} (65)
=\displaystyle= âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2âˆ’2â€‹Î·â€‹âŸ¨ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—,âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âŸ©+Î·2â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°22ğœ‚subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğœ‚2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}-2\eta\langle\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*},\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\rangle+\eta^{2}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}
â‰¤(a)ğ‘\displaystyle\overset{(a)}{\leq} âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2âˆ’2â€‹Î·â€‹(Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)+Î¼2â€‹âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2)+Î·2â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°22ğœ‚ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ¹superscriptğ°ğœ‡2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°2superscriptğœ‚2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}-2\eta\left(F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}\right)+\eta^{2}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}
â‰¤(b)ğ‘\displaystyle\overset{(b)}{\leq} (1âˆ’Î·â€‹Î¼)â€‹âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2âˆ’2â€‹Î·â€‹(Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—))+2â€‹Î·2â€‹Lâ€‹(Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—))1ğœ‚ğœ‡superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°22ğœ‚ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ¹superscriptğ°2superscriptğœ‚2ğ¿ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ¹superscriptğ°\displaystyle(1-\eta\mu)\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}-2\eta(F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*}))+2\eta^{2}L(F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*}))
â‰¤(c)ğ‘\displaystyle\overset{(c)}{\leq} (1âˆ’Î·â€‹Î¼)â€‹âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2.1ğœ‚ğœ‡superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°2\displaystyle(1-\eta\mu)\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}.

(a) comes from the Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strong convexity of Fğ¹F, which ensures that

Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)â‰¥Fâ€‹(ğ°t)+âŸ¨âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t),ğ°âˆ—âˆ’ğ°tâŸ©+Î¼2â€‹âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2.ğ¹superscriptğ°ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‡2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°2\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\geq F(\mathbf{w}_{t})+\langle\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}),\mathbf{w}^{*}-\mathbf{w}_{t}\rangle+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}. (66)

(b) comes from the Lğ¿L-smoothness of Fğ¹F, which ensures that

âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥2â‰¤2â€‹Lâ€‹(Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)).superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡22ğ¿ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ¹superscriptğ°\displaystyle\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}\leq 2L(F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})). (67)

(c) is from the requirement Î·â‰¤1/Lğœ‚1ğ¿\eta\leq 1/L. Therefore, from (64) and (65),

âˆ¥ğ°t+1âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â‰¤1âˆ’Î·â€‹Î¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+Î·â€‹Î”.delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1superscriptğ°1ğœ‚ğœ‡delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°ğœ‚Î”\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t+1}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq\sqrt{1-\eta\mu}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\eta\Delta. (68)

By induction, it can be shown that

âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â‰¤(1âˆ’Ï)tâ€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+2â€‹Î”Î¼,delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°superscript1ğœŒğ‘¡delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°2Î”ğœ‡\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq(1-\rho)^{t}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{2\Delta}{\mu}, (69)

with Ï=Î·â€‹Î¼/2ğœŒğœ‚ğœ‡2\rho=\eta\mu/2.

A.2 Proof of Lemma 2

Our proof follows [9] and [19] with some slight improvements.

To begin with, we prove that ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆˆğ’²subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ’²\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t})\in\mathcal{W} for t=1,â€¦,tmâˆ’1ğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘š1t=1,\ldots,t_{m}-1, such that the projection has no effect, i.e. Î ğ’²â€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t))=ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t)subscriptÎ ğ’²subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡\Pi_{\mathcal{W}}(\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t}))=\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t}). Note that

âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+Î·â€‹Î”.delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°ğœ‚Î”\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\eta\Delta. (70)

Recall that Î·=1/Lğœ‚1ğ¿\eta=1/L,

âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2} =\displaystyle= âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2âˆ’2â€‹Î·â€‹âŸ¨âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t),ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âŸ©+Î·2â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°22ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°superscriptğœ‚2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}-2\eta\langle\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}),\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\rangle+\eta^{2}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2} (71)
â‰¤\displaystyle\leq âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2âˆ’2â€‹Î·Lâ€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥2+Î·2â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°22ğœ‚ğ¿superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2superscriptğœ‚2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}-\frac{2\eta}{L}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}+\eta^{2}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}
=\displaystyle= âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2âˆ’1L2â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°21superscriptğ¿2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}-\frac{1}{L^{2}}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}
â‰¤\displaystyle\leq âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2.superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}.

Therefore

âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+Î”L.delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°Î”ğ¿\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{\Delta}{L}. (72)

Now prove that for t=0,1,â€¦,tmâˆ’1ğ‘¡01â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘š1t=0,1,\ldots,t_{m}-1,

âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’gâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+tâ€‹Î”Ldelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°ğ‘¡Î”ğ¿\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-g(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{t\Delta}{L} (73)

by induction. (73) for t=0ğ‘¡0t=0 is trivial. If (73) holds for tğ‘¡t, then

âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+tmâ€‹Î”Lâ‰¤2â€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥,delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šÎ”ğ¿2delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{t_{m}\Delta}{L}\leq 2\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert, (74)

hence ğ°tâˆ’gâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆˆğ’²subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ’²\mathbf{w}_{t}-g(\mathbf{w}_{t})\in\mathcal{W}, and ğ°t+1=Î ğ’²â€‹(ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t))=ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t)subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1subscriptÎ ğ’²subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡\mathbf{w}_{t+1}=\Pi_{\mathcal{W}}(\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t}))=\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t}). Hence, at time step t+1ğ‘¡1t+1,

âˆ¥ğ°t+1âˆ’Î·â€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t+1)âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ¥ğ°t+1âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+Î”Lâ‰¤âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+(t+1)â€‹Î”L.delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1ğœ‚ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1superscriptğ°delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1superscriptğ°Î”ğ¿delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°ğ‘¡1Î”ğ¿\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t+1}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t+1})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t+1}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{\Delta}{L}\leq\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{(t+1)\Delta}{L}. (75)

Proof of (73) is complete. With (73), it can be shown that ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆˆğ’²subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ’²\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t})\in\mathcal{W} for all t=0,1,â€¦,tmâˆ’1ğ‘¡01â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘š1t=0,1,\ldots,t_{m}-1. We can then study the algorithm without projection.

Since Fğ¹F is Lğ¿L-smooth,

Fâ€‹(ğ°t+1)ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t+1}) â‰¤\displaystyle\leq Fâ€‹(ğ°t)+âŸ¨âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t),ğ°t+1âˆ’ğ°tâŸ©+L2â€‹âˆ¥ğ°t+1âˆ’ğ°tâˆ¥2ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ¿2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t})+\langle\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}),\mathbf{w}_{t+1}-\mathbf{w}_{t}\rangle+\frac{L}{2}\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t+1}-\mathbf{w}_{t}\right\rVert^{2} (76)
=\displaystyle= Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Î·â€‹âŸ¨âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t),gâ€‹(ğ°t)âŸ©+12â€‹Lâ€‹Î·2â€‹âˆ¥gâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥2ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡12ğ¿superscriptğœ‚2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\eta\langle\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}),g(\mathbf{w}_{t})\rangle+\frac{1}{2}L\eta^{2}\left\lVert g(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}
=\displaystyle= Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Î·â€‹âŸ¨âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t),gâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âŸ©âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥2ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\eta\langle\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}),g(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\rangle-\eta\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}
+12â€‹Lâ€‹Î·2â€‹(âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥2+2â€‹âŸ¨âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t),gâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âŸ©+âˆ¥gâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥2)12ğ¿superscriptğœ‚2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡22âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2\displaystyle+\frac{1}{2}L\eta^{2}\left(\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}+2\langle\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t}),g(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\rangle+\left\lVert g(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}\right)
=\displaystyle= Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’12â€‹Lâ€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥2+12â€‹Lâ€‹Î”2.ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡12ğ¿superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡212ğ¿superscriptÎ”2\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\frac{1}{2L}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}+\frac{1}{2L}\Delta^{2}.

We discuss two cases.

Case 1. âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥â‰¥2â€‹Î”delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2Î”\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert\geq\sqrt{2}\Delta for all t=0,1,â€¦,tmâˆ’1ğ‘¡01â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘š1t=0,1,\ldots,t_{m}-1. Then from (76), define D=âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥ğ·delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°D=\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert, then

Fâ€‹(ğ°t+1)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1ğ¹superscriptğ°\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t+1})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*}) â‰¤\displaystyle\leq Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)âˆ’14â€‹Lâ€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥2ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ¹superscriptğ°14ğ¿superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})-\frac{1}{4L}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2} (77)
â‰¤\displaystyle\leq Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)âˆ’14â€‹Lâ€‹âˆ¥ğ°âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥2â€‹(Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—))2ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ¹superscriptğ°14ğ¿superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ°superscriptğ°2superscriptğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ¹superscriptğ°2\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})-\frac{1}{4L\left\lVert\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}}(F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*}))^{2}
â‰¤\displaystyle\leq Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)âˆ’116â€‹Lâ€‹D2â€‹(Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—))2,ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ¹superscriptğ°116ğ¿superscriptğ·2superscriptğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ¹superscriptğ°2\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})-\frac{1}{16LD^{2}}(F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*}))^{2},

in which the last step comes from (59). Denote

et:=Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—),assignsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ¹superscriptğ°\displaystyle e_{t}:=F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*}), (78)

then

et+1â‰¤etâˆ’116â€‹Lâ€‹D2â€‹et2,subscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡116ğ¿superscriptğ·2superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡2\displaystyle e_{t+1}\leq e_{t}-\frac{1}{16LD^{2}}e_{t}^{2}, (79)

and

1et+1=1etâ€‹(1âˆ’116â€‹Lâ€‹D2â€‹et)â‰¥1etâ€‹(1+116â€‹Lâ€‹D2â€‹et)=1et+116â€‹Lâ€‹D2,1subscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡11subscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡1116ğ¿superscriptğ·2subscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡1116ğ¿superscriptğ·2subscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡116ğ¿superscriptğ·2\displaystyle\frac{1}{e_{t+1}}=\frac{1}{e_{t}\left(1-\frac{1}{16LD^{2}}e_{t}\right)}\geq\frac{1}{e_{t}}\left(1+\frac{1}{16LD^{2}}e_{t}\right)=\frac{1}{e_{t}}+\frac{1}{16LD^{2}}, (80)

hence

1etmâ‰¥tm16â€‹Lâ€‹D2,1subscriptğ‘’subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘š16ğ¿superscriptğ·2\displaystyle\frac{1}{e_{t_{m}}}\geq\frac{t_{m}}{16LD^{2}}, (81)

thus

Fâ€‹(ğ°tm)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)â‰¤16â€‹Lâ€‹D2tm=16â€‹Dâ€‹Î”.ğ¹subscriptğ°subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ¹superscriptğ°16ğ¿superscriptğ·2subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘š16ğ·Î”\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t_{m}})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq\frac{16LD^{2}}{t_{m}}=16D\Delta. (82)

Case 2. âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°k)âˆ¥<2â€‹Î”delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘˜2Î”\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{k})\right\rVert<\sqrt{2}\Delta for some kâˆˆ{0,1,â€¦,tmâˆ’1}ğ‘˜01â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘š1k\in\{0,1,\ldots,t_{m}-1\}. Then

Fâ€‹(ğ°k)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)â‰¤âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°k)âˆ¥â€‹ğ°kâˆ’ğ°âˆ—â‰¤2â€‹2â€‹Dâ€‹Î”.ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘˜ğ¹superscriptğ°delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘˜subscriptğ°ğ‘˜superscriptğ°22ğ·Î”\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{k})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{k})\right\rVert{\mathbf{w}_{k}-\mathbf{w}^{*}}\leq 2\sqrt{2}D\Delta. (83)

Now prove

Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)â‰¤2â€‹2â€‹Dâ€‹Î”,ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ¹superscriptğ°22ğ·Î”\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq 2\sqrt{2}D\Delta, (84)

for t=k,k+1,â€¦,tmğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘št=k,k+1,\ldots,t_{m} by induction. (84) with t=kğ‘¡ğ‘˜t=k obviously hold. If (84) holds for tğ‘¡t, at t+1ğ‘¡1t+1, if âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t+1)âˆ¥<2â€‹Î”delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡12Î”\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t+1})\right\rVert<\sqrt{2}\Delta, then (84) holds. Otherwise, by (76),

Fâ€‹(ğ°t+1)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)â‰¤Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)âˆ’14â€‹Lâ€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ¥2â‰¤Fâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)â‰¤2â€‹2â€‹Dâ€‹Î”.ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1ğ¹superscriptğ°ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ¹superscriptğ°14ğ¿superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡2ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ¹superscriptğ°22ğ·Î”\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t+1})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})-\frac{1}{4L}\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}\leq F(\mathbf{w}_{t})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq 2\sqrt{2}D\Delta. (85)

Therefore (84) is proved. Hence

Fâ€‹(ğ°tm)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)â‰¤2â€‹2â€‹Dâ€‹Î”.ğ¹subscriptğ°subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ¹superscriptğ°22ğ·Î”\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t_{m}})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq 2\sqrt{2}D\Delta. (86)

Combine (82) for Case 1 and (86) for Case 2, and recall that D=âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥ğ·delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°D=\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert,

Fâ€‹(ğ°tm)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ°âˆ—)â‰¤16â€‹âˆ¥ğ°0âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥â€‹Î”.ğ¹subscriptğ°subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ¹superscriptğ°16delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°0superscriptğ°Î”\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{t_{m}})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq 16\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{0}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert\Delta. (87)

The proof of Lemma 2 is complete.

A.3 Proof of Lemma 3

âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’Î·â€‹gâ€‹(ğ°t)âˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘”subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta g(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert â‰¤\displaystyle\leq âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+Î·â€‹(âˆ¥âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ¥+âˆ¥gâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ¥)delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°ğœ‚delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¹ğ°delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘”ğ°âˆ‡ğ¹ğ°\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\eta(\left\lVert\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\right\rVert+\left\lVert g(\mathbf{w})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\right\rVert) (88)
â‰¤\displaystyle\leq âˆ¥ğ°tâˆ’ğ°âˆ—âˆ¥+1Lâ€‹(M+Î”).delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptğ°1ğ¿ğ‘€Î”\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rVert+\frac{1}{L}(M+\Delta).
